user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GenericSeek_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_GenericSeek_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, int32 offset, uint32 whence)
{
    int                             where;
    off_t                           os_result;
    int32                           retval;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    switch (whence)
    {
        case OS_SEEK_SET:
            where = SEEK_SET;
            break;
        case OS_SEEK_CUR:
            where = SEEK_CUR;
            break;
        case OS_SEEK_END:
            where = SEEK_END;
            break;
        default:
            return OS_ERROR;
    }

    os_result = lseek(impl->fd, (off_t)offset, where);
    if (os_result == (off_t)-1)
    {
        if (errno == ESPIPE)
        {
            /*
             * this means the user tried to seek on a pipe, socket,
             * or other fifo-like handle that doesn't support seeking.
             *
             * Use a different error code to differentiate from an
             * error involving a bad whence/offset
             */
            retval = OS_ERR_OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED;
        }
        else
        {
            /*
             * Most likely the "whence" and/or "offset" combo was not valid.
             */
            OS_DEBUG("lseek: %s\n", strerror(errno));
            retval = OS_ERROR;
        }
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * convert value to int32 type for returning to caller.
         * Note that this could potentially overflow an int32
         * for a large file seek.
         */
        retval = (int32)os_result;
    }

    return retval;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GenericSeek_Impl:
#define OS_SEEK_SET 0
...
#define OS_SEEK_CUR 1
...
#define OS_SEEK_END 2
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_lseek(osal_id_t filedes, int32 offset, uint32 whence)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Make sure the file descriptor is legit before using it */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, filedes, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_GenericSeek_Impl(&token, offset, whence);
        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_ERR_OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED (-38)
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other code fragments in the function do not appear to present reachability concerns and therefore need not be investigated for Rule 2.1: - The switch cases for OS_SEEK_SET/OS_SEEK_CUR/OS_SEEK_END assign 'where' and fall through to the lseek call; these are standard, reachable paths when a valid whence value is supplied. - The impl lookup (impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(...)) and subsequent use of impl->fd are normal runtime operations; validity of the token is checked by the caller wrapper (OS_lseek) before calling this implementation. - The lseek call itself is a runtime system call whose success/failure paths are already exercised by the if (os_result == (off_t)-1) fragment that has been included above. - Declarations and the final 'return retval;' are reachable in normal control flow except when earlier returns (e.g. the switch default) are taken; those earlier returns are included in the suspicious list. - The OS_DEBUG macro is defined as an empty macro in the provided definitions; this removes the logging call at compile time but does not, by itself, create unreachable code in other parts. The listed fragments are those that could be unreachable or conditionally unreachable depending on upstream invariants or platform behavior and therefore should be investigated for compliance with MISRA C Rule 2.1.
